text:
“Look how deserted Jerusalem is!
    Once the city was crowded with people.
    Once it was important among the nations.
        Now it is a widow.
    Once it was a princess among the provinces.
        Now it does forced labor.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Jerusalem cries bitterly at night with tears running down its cheeks.
    Out of all those who love the city, no one offers it comfort.
    All of Jerusalem’s friends have betrayed it and become its enemies.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Judah has been exiled after much suffering and harsh treatment.
    Its people live among the nations; they find no rest.
        Those who chased them caught up with them
            in places where there was no way out.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“The roads to Zion are deserted.
    No one comes to the annual festivals.
    No one passes through any of its gates.
        Its priests are groaning.
        Its young women are made to suffer.
            Zion is bitter.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Its opponents are now in control.
    Its enemies have no worries.
    Yahweh made Zion suffer for its many rebellious acts.
    Its children go ahead of their opponents into captivity.
speaker: Narrator

text:
All splendor has abandoned the people of Zion.
    Its influential people were like deer that couldn’t find any pasture.
        They ran without any strength ahead of the hunters.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Now, during its suffering and oppression,
    Jerusalem remembers all the treasures it had from ancient times,
        when its people fell into the power of their enemies
            with no one to help them.
    Their opponents looked on, and they laughed at Jerusalem’s downfall.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Jerusalem has sinned so much that it has become a filthy thing.
    Everyone who used to honor it now despises it.
        They’ve seen it naked.
            Jerusalem groans and turns away.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Jerusalem’s own filth covers its clothes.
    It gave no thought to its future.
    Its downfall was shocking.
        No one offers it comfort.
            ‘O Yahweh, look at my suffering,
                because my enemies have triumphed.’
speaker: Narrator

text:
The enemies laid their hands on all of the city’s treasures.
    Jerusalem has seen the nations enter the holy place.
        ‘O Lord, they are the same people
            you have forbidden to enter your congregation.’
speaker: Narrator

text:
All the people are groaning as they beg for bread.
    They trade their treasures for food to keep themselves alive.
        ‘O Yahweh, look and see how despised I am!’”
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Doesn’t this affect all of you who pass by?
    Look and see if there’s any pain
    like the pain that Yahweh has caused me,
    like the pain that he has made me suffer on the day of his fierce anger.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He sent fire from above.
    He made it go deep into my bones.
        He spread a net for my feet.
        He made me turn back.
        He has left me devastated.
        He has made me sick all day long.
speaker: Narrator

text:
My rebellious acts are a heavy burden for me.
    They were tied together by Yahweh’s own hands.
    They were tied around my neck.
        He has weakened me with them.
        Adonay has handed me over to people I cannot oppose.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Adonay has treated all the warriors inside my walls with contempt.
    He called an army to defeat my young men.
        Adonay trampled the people of Judah in a winepress.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I’m crying because of all these things.
    My eyes—my eyes flow with tears.
        No one can give me the comfort I need to keep me alive.
            Everyone is too far away from me.
                My children are devastated because my enemies have won.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
Zion holds out its hands.
    No one offers it comfort.
    Yahweh has given this order about Jacob:
    His own neighbors will become his opponents.
    Jerusalem has become a filthy thing among them.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Yahweh is right in what he did,
    because I rebelled against his word.
    Please listen, all you people, and look at my pain.
    My young women and young men have gone into captivity.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I called for those who love me, but they betrayed me.
    My priests and leaders breathed their last breath in the city,
        looking for food to keep themselves alive.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“O Yahweh, see the distress I’m in!
    My stomach is churning.
    My heart is pounding because I’ve been very bitter.
    In the streets swords kill my children.
    Inside the houses it’s like death.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“All my enemies have heard that I am groaning.
    No one offers me comfort.
    All my enemies have heard about my disaster.
    They are happy that you did it.
        You have allowed the day to come, the one that you had announced.
            Let my enemies be like me now.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Recall all of their wickedness.
    Then deal with them as you have dealt with me
        because of all my rebellious acts.
            I groan so much and feel so sick at heart.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Look how Adonay has covered the people of Zion
    with the cloud of his anger!
    He has thrown down Israel’s beauty from heaven to earth.
    He didn’t even remember his footstool on the day of his anger.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Adonay swallowed up all of Jacob’s pastures without any pity.
    He tore down the fortified cities of Judah in his fury.
    He brought the kingdom of Judah and its leaders
        down to the ground in dishonor.
speaker: Narrator

text:
In his burning anger he cut off all of Israel’s strength.
    He withdrew his right hand when they faced their enemy.
    He burned like a raging fire in the land of Jacob,
        destroying everything around him.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Like an enemy he bent his bow.
    Like an opponent his right hand held the arrow steady.
    He killed all the beautiful people.
    He poured out his fury like fire on the tent of Zion’s people.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Adonay became an enemy.
    He swallowed up Israel.
    He swallowed up all of its palaces.
    He destroyed its strongholds.
    He made the people of Judah mourn and moan.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He stripped his own booth as if it were a garden
    and destroyed his own festivals.
    Yahweh wiped out the memory of festivals and days of worship in Zion.
    He expelled kings and priests because of his fierce anger.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Adonay rejected his altar and disowned his holy place.
    He handed the walls of Zion’s palaces over to its enemies.
        The enemies made noise in Yahweh’s temple
            as though it were a festival day.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Yahweh planned to destroy the wall of Zion’s people.
    He marked it off with a line.
    He didn’t take his hand away until he had swallowed it up.
    He made the towers and walls mourn.
        They are completely dejected.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Zion’s gates have sunk into the ground.
    The Lord destroyed and shattered the bars across its gates.
    Its king and influential people are scattered among the nations.
    There is no longer any instruction from Moses’ Teachings.
    Its prophets can find no visions from Yahweh.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The respected leaders of Zion’s people sit silently on the ground.
    They throw dirt on their heads and put on sackcloth.
    The young women of Jerusalem bow their heads to the ground.
speaker: Narrator

text:
My eyes are worn out with tears.
    My stomach is churning.
    My heart is poured out on the ground
    because of the destruction of my people.
    Little children and infants faint in the city streets.
speaker: Narrator

text:
They’re asking their mothers for some bread and wine
    as they faint like wounded people in the city streets.
        Their lives dwindle away in their mothers’ arms.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“What example can I give you?
    What parallel can I show you, people of Jerusalem?
    What comparison can I make that will comfort you, beloved people of Zion?
    Your wounds are as deep as the sea.
    Who can heal you?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Your prophets saw misleading visions about you.
    They painted a good picture of you.
    They didn’t expose your guilt in order to make things better again.
    They gave you false prophecies that misled you.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Everyone who walks along the road shakes a fist at you.
    They hiss and shake their heads at Jerusalem’s people:
        ‘Is this the city they used to call absolutely beautiful,
            the joy of the whole world?’
speaker: Narrator

text:
All your enemies gawk at you.
    They hiss and grit their teeth.
    They say, ‘We’ve swallowed it up.
        Yes, this is the day we’ve been waiting for.
            At last we have seen it!’
speaker: Narrator

text:
Yahweh has accomplished what he had planned to do.
    He carried out the threat he announced long ago.
    He tore you down without any pity, Jerusalem.
    He made your enemies gloat over you.
    He raised the weapons of your opponents.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The hearts of Jerusalem’s people
    cried out to Adonay, the wall of Zion’s people.
        Let your tears run down like a river day and night.
            Don’t let them stop.
                Don’t let your eyes rest.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Get up! Cry out at night, every hour on the hour.
    Pour your heart out like water in the presence of Adonay.
        Lift up your hands to him in prayer
            for the life of your little children
                who faint from hunger at every street corner.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
“O Yahweh, look and consider:
    Have you ever treated anyone like this?
        Should women eat their own children,
            the children they have nursed?
        Should priests and prophets be killed in Adonay’s holy place?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Young and old lie on the ground in the streets.
    My young women and men are cut down by swords.
    You killed them on the day of your anger.
    You slaughtered them without any pity.
speaker: Narrator

text:
You have invited those who terrorize me on every side,
    as though they were invited to a festival.
    No one escaped or survived on the day of Yahweh’s anger.
    My enemy has murdered the children I nursed and raised.”
speaker: Narrator

text: “I am the man who has experienced suffering under the rod of Yahweh’s fury.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Yahweh has driven me away
    and made me walk in darkness instead of light.
speaker: Narrator

text: He beat me again and again all day long.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He has made my flesh and my skin waste away.
    He has broken my bones.
speaker: Narrator

text: He has attacked me and surrounded me with bitterness and hardship.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He has made me live in darkness,
    like those who died a long time ago.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He has blocked me so that I can’t get out.
    He has put heavy chains on me.
speaker: Narrator

text: Even when I cry and call for help, he shuts out my prayer.
speaker: Narrator

text: He has blocked my way with cut stones and made my paths crooked.
speaker: Narrator

text: He is like a bear waiting to ambush me, like a lion in hiding.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He has forced me off the road I was taking, torn me to pieces,
    and left me with nothing.
speaker: Narrator

text: He has drawn his bow and made me the target for his arrows.
speaker: Narrator

text: He has shot the arrows from his quiver into my heart.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I have become a laughingstock to all my people.
    All day long they make fun of me with their songs.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He has filled me with bitterness.
    He has made me drink wormwood.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He has ground my teeth with gravel.
    He has trampled me into the dust.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“My soul has been kept from enjoying peace.
    I have forgotten what happiness is.
speaker: Narrator

text: I said, ‘I’ve lost my strength to live and my hope in the Lord.’
speaker: Narrator

text:
Remember my suffering and my aimless wandering,
    the wormwood and poison.
speaker: Narrator

text: My soul continues to remember these things and is so discouraged.
speaker: Narrator

text: “The reason I can still find hope is that I keep this one thing in mind:
speaker: Narrator

text:
the Lord’s mercy.
    We were not completely wiped out.
        His compassion is never limited.
speaker: Narrator

text:
It is new every morning.
    His faithfulness is great.
speaker: Narrator

text:
My soul can say, ‘The Lord is my lot in life.
    That is why I find hope in him.’
speaker: Narrator

text:
The Lord is good to those who wait for him,
    to anyone who seeks help from him.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“It is good to continue to hope and wait silently
    for the Lord to save us.
speaker: Narrator

text: It is good for people to endure burdens when they’re young.
speaker: Narrator

text:
They should sit alone and remain silent
    because Yahweh has laid these burdens on them.
speaker: Narrator

text:
They should put their mouths in the dust.
    Maybe a reason to hope exists.
speaker: Narrator

text:
They should turn their cheeks to the one who strikes them
    and take their fill of insults.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Adonay will not reject such people forever.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Even if he makes us suffer,
    he will have compassion
        in keeping with the richness of his mercy.
speaker: Narrator

text: He does not willingly bring suffering or grief to anyone,
speaker: Narrator

text: crush any prisoner on earth underfoot,
speaker: Narrator

text: deny people their rights in the presence of Elyon,
speaker: Narrator

text:
or deprive people of justice in court.
    Adonay isn’t happy to see these things.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Who was it who spoke and it came into being?
    It was Adonay who gave the order.
speaker: Narrator

text: Both good and bad come from the mouth of the Most High God.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Why should any living mortal (any person)
    complain about being punished for sin?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Let us look closely at our ways and examine them
    and then return to Yahweh.
speaker: Narrator

text: Let us raise our hearts and hands to El in heaven.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“We have been disobedient and rebellious.
    You haven’t forgiven us.
speaker: Narrator

text:
You covered yourself with anger and pursued us.
    You killed without pity.
speaker: Narrator

text:
You covered yourself with a cloud
    so that no prayer could get through it.
speaker: Narrator

text: You made us the scum and trash of the nations.
speaker: Narrator

text: All our enemies gawk at us.
speaker: Narrator

text: Panic and pitfalls have found us, so have devastation and destruction.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Streams of tears run down from my eyes
    over the ruin of my dear people.
speaker: Narrator

text: My eyes will keep flowing without stopping for a moment
speaker: Narrator

text: until Yahweh looks down from heaven and sees.
speaker: Narrator

text:
What I see with my eyes disturbs me deeply
    because of all the young women in my city.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Those who were my enemies for no reason hunted me like a bird.
speaker: Narrator

text: They threw me alive into a pit and threw rocks at me.
speaker: Narrator

text: Water flowed over my head. I thought I was finished.
speaker: Narrator

text: “I call your name from the deepest pit, O Yahweh.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Listen to my cry for help.
    Don’t close your ears when I cry out for relief.
speaker: Narrator

text: Be close at hand when I call to you. You told me not to be afraid.
speaker: Narrator

text: Plead my case for me, O Adonay. Reclaim my life.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Look at the wrong that has been done to me, O Yahweh.
    Give me a fair verdict.
speaker: Narrator

text: Look at all their malice, all their plots against me.
speaker: Narrator

text: Listen to their insults, all their plots against me.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The words and thoughts of those who attack me
    are directed against me all day long.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Look at them! Whether they are sitting or standing,
    they make fun of me in their songs.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Pay them back, O Yahweh, for what they deserve,
    for what their own hands have done.
speaker: Narrator

text: Make them stubborn. Let your curse be on them.
speaker: Narrator

text: Pursue them in anger, and wipe them out from under Yahweh’s heaven.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Look how the gold has become tarnished!
    The fine gold has changed!
    The sacred stones are scattered at every street corner.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Zion’s precious children, who are worth their weight in fine gold,
    are now treated like clay pots,
        like those made by a potter’s hands.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Even jackals offer their breasts to nurse their young,
    but the women of my people are as cruel as wild ostriches.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The tongues of nursing infants stick to the roofs of their mouths
    because of their thirst.
    Little children beg for bread,
    but no one will break off a piece for them.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Those who used to eat delicacies are now destitute in the streets.
    Those who used to wear expensive clothes now pick through piles of garbage.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The punishment for my people’s wickedness has been more severe
    than the punishment for the sins of Sodom.
        Sodom was destroyed instantly, without one human hand touching it.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Zion’s princes were purer than snow, whiter than milk.
    Their bodies were more pink than coral.
    Their hair was like sapphires.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Their faces are now blacker than soot.
    No one recognizes them on the streets.
    Their skin has shriveled on their bones.
        It has become as dry as bark.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Those who were killed with swords are better off
    than those who are dying from starvation.
    Those who were stabbed bled to death.
    The others are dying because there is nothing in the fields to eat.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The hands of loving mothers cooked their own children.
    The children were used for food by my people
        when they were being destroyed by a blockade.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Yahweh’s fury has accomplished his purpose.
    He unleashed his burning anger.
    He started a fire in Zion that even burned its foundations.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Neither the kings of the earth nor anyone living on earth could believe
    that enemies or invaders would ever get through the gates of Jerusalem.
speaker: Narrator

text:
They got through because of the sins of Jerusalem’s prophets
    and the crimes of its priests,
        who spilled the blood of righteous people within it.
speaker: Narrator

text:
My people staggered blindly through the streets.
    They were so contaminated with bloodstains
        that no one would touch their clothes.
speaker: Narrator

text:
‘Get away! You’re unclean,’ people yelled at them.
    ‘Get away! Get away! Don’t touch anyone.’
    When they fled and wandered around,
        the people of the nations said, ‘They can’t stay here any longer.’
speaker: Narrator

text:
Yahweh himself has scattered them.
    He will no longer look favorably on them.
        They no longer respected the priests,
            nor did they honor their older leaders.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
“We are still straining our eyes, trying in vain to find help.
    We waited and waited for a nation that didn’t save us.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The enemy kept tracking us down,
    so we couldn’t even go out into the streets.
        Our end was near.
        Our time was up.
        Our end had come.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Those who were hunting us were faster than eagles in the sky.
    They chased us in the mountains and ambushed us in the wilderness.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The person Yahweh anointed as king, who is the breath of our life,
    was caught in their pits.
        We had thought that we would live
            in our king’s shadow among the nations.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Rejoice and be glad, people of Edom, inhabitants of the country of Uz.
    The cup of the Lord’s fury will be passed to you next.
        You’ll get drunk and take off all your clothes.
speaker: Narrator

text:
People of Zion, the punishment for your wickedness will end.
    Yahweh will not let you remain in exile.
    People of Edom, he will punish you for your wickedness.
    He will expose your sins.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Remember, O Yahweh, what has happened to us.
    Take a look at our disgrace!
speaker: Narrator

text:
“The land we inherited has been turned over to strangers.
    Our homes have been turned over to foreigners.
speaker: Narrator

text:
We are orphans without a father.
    Our mothers are like widows.
speaker: Narrator

text:
We have to pay to drink our own water.
    We have to pay to chop our own wood.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Our enemies are breathing down our necks.
    We are worn out and not permitted to rest.
speaker: Narrator

text: We had to beg Egypt and Assyria for food.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Our ancestors sinned.
    Now they are gone,
        but we have to take the punishment for their wickedness.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Slaves rule us.
    There is no one to rescue us from them.
speaker: Narrator

text:
To get our food, we have to risk our lives
    in the heat of the desert.
speaker: Narrator

text: Our skin is as hot as an oven from the burning heat of starvation.
speaker: Narrator

text: Women in Zion are raped, so are the girls in the cities of Judah.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Our leaders are hung by their hands.
    Our older leaders are shown no respect.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Our young men work at the mill,
    and our boys stagger under loads of wood.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Our older leaders have stopped meeting at the city gate,
    and our young men no longer play their music.
speaker: Narrator

text:
There is no joy left in our hearts.
    Our dancing has turned into mourning.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The crown has fallen from our head.
    Because we have sinned, it has been disastrous for us.
speaker: Narrator

text:
This is why we feel sick.
    This is why our eyes see less and less.
speaker: Narrator

text: Foxes roam around on Mount Zion, which lies in ruins.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“But you, O Yahweh, sit enthroned forever,
    and your reign continues throughout every generation.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Why have you completely forgotten us?
    Why have you abandoned us for such a long time?
speaker: Narrator

text:
O Yahweh, bring us back to you, and we’ll come back.
    Give us back the life we had long ago,
speaker: Narrator

text:
unless you have completely rejected us
    and are very angry with us.”
speaker: Narrator
